headline: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Recap
summary: Nvidia’s shares fell 5.5% despite record income as investors' high expectations for AI bellwethers continue to create a difficult bar for companies to clear.  One particular problem, notes Heard columnist Dan Gallagher, is that the company’s runaway success could be seen as a sign of the destabilization to come, given the massive amounts of capital-spending filling its coffers are financially weakening the world’s largest companies from Amazon to Microsoft.  The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained relatively flat and Treasury yields inched lower.

raw.headline: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Recap
raw.summary: Nvidia’s shares fell 5.5% despite record income as investors' high expectations for AI bellwethers continue to create a difficult bar for companies to clear.  One particular problem, notes Heard columnist Dan Gallagher, is that the company’s runaway success could be seen as a sign of the destabilization to come, given the massive amounts of capital-spending filling its coffers are financially weakening the world’s largest companies from Amazon to Microsoft.  The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained relatively flat and Treasury yields inched lower.

headline: Nvidia’s Market Cap Posts Biggest Drop Since March 2025—Despite Blowout Earnings
summary: Nvidia  was getting a ton of praise on Thursday after its fourth-quarter earnings beat analysts’ expectations—but the artificial-intelligence chip maker’s stock plunged 5.5% on Thursday.  Nvidia lost $259 billion in market cap, its largest market cap loss since March 3, 2025, and the seventh largest one-day market cap loss of any U.S. company on record, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  The  fell 0.5%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite dropped by 1.2% as investors dumped megacap tech stocks.

raw.headline: Nvidia’s Market Cap Posts Biggest Drop Since March 2025—Despite Blowout Earnings
raw.summary: Nvidia  was getting a ton of praise on Thursday after its fourth-quarter earnings beat analysts’ expectations—but the artificial-intelligence chip maker’s stock plunged 5.5% on Thursday.  Nvidia lost $259 billion in market cap, its largest market cap loss since March 3, 2025, and the seventh largest one-day market cap loss of any U.S. company on record, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  The  fell 0.5%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite dropped by 1.2% as investors dumped megacap tech stocks.

headline: Dell forecasts fiscal 2027 revenue above estimates on rising AI server demand
summary: Dell forecast fiscal 2027 revenue above Wall Street estimates on Thursday, betting on growing demand for its artificial ‌intelligence-optimized servers, sending its shares up around 11% in extended trading. The company ‌also announced a 20% hike in its cash dividend and an additional $10 billion for its share repurchase ​program. Big Tech firms, such as Alphabet, Microsoft, Amazon and Meta, are expected to spend at least $630 billion to build AI infrastructure this year, which would boost demand for vendors like Dell and rival Super Micro Computer.

raw.summary: Dell forecast fiscal 2027 revenue above Wall Street estimates on Thursday, betting on growing demand for its artificial ‌intelligence-optimized servers, sending its shares up around 11% in extended trading. The company ‌also announced a 20% hike in its cash dividend and an additional $10 billion for its share repurchase ​program. Big Tech firms, such as Alphabet, Microsoft, Amazon and Meta, are expected to spend at least $630 billion to build AI infrastructure this year, which would boost demand for vendors like Dell and rival Super Micro Computer.

headline: Nvidia Stock Is On Track for Its Worst Day in Months—Despite Blowout Earnings
summary: Nvidia  was getting a ton of praise on Thursday after its fourth-quarter earnings beat analysts’ expectations—but the artificial-intelligence chip maker’s stock plunged in intraday trading.  Shares fell 5.6% to $184.66, on pace for their largest percentage loss since April 2025.  D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria wrote in a research note that Nvidia’s results were a “notable beat over expectations,” adding that he sees “no reason to doubt compute-demand given the accelerating trajectory of AI progress.”

headline: US filings for jobless aid rise modestly to 212,000 as layoffs remain at historically healthy levels
summary: Slightly more Americans applied for unemployment benefits last week as layoffs remain at relatively healthy levels.  The number of Americans filing for jobless aid for the week ending Feb. 21 rose by 4,000 to 212,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported Thursday.  Filings for unemployment benefits are viewed as representative of U.S. layoffs and are close to a real-time indicator of the health of the job market.

headline: Here's What Wall Street Is Saying About Nvidia's Record Quarter
summary: Stock analysts raced to lift forecasts for Nvidia's sales and earnings growth after the AI chipmaker posted a 94% rise in quarterly profit and record revenue on Wednesday.  Dan Ives of Wedbush, a staunch AI optimist, described the results as "like watching Michael Jordan in his first few years for the Chicago Bulls."  Ives said the results show demand for Nvidia's chips is even stronger than anticipated.

headline: Why Nvidia’s Huge Numbers Don’t Settle the Latest AI Fears
summary: Nvidia  now makes more revenue in a single quarter than most other chip companies generate in an entire year.  Nvidia projected an even higher growth rate for the current quarter, and that forecast actually beat Wall Street’s consensus target by the widest range in two years, according to FactSet data.  Nvidia’s share price has gone through other periods of turbulence over the past three years, as investors have sporadically worried about blowout AI spending creating a bubble that could suddenly burst.

headline: Nvidia Earnings Get Rave Reviews on Wall Street. Why the Stock Isn’t Rallying.
summary: Nvidia  was getting a ton of praise on Thursday after its fourth-quarter earnings beat analysts’ expectations—but the artificial-intelligence chip maker’s stock failed to catch fire ahead of the opening bell.  D.A. Davidson analyst Gil Luria wrote in a research note that Nvidia’s results were a “notable beat over expectations,” adding that he sees “no reason to doubt compute-demand given the accelerating trajectory of AI progress.”  KeyBanc analyst John Vinh raised some estimates and said that guidance had “solidly exceeded expectations.”

headline: Amazon's $50 billion OpenAI investment may depend on IPO or AGI, The Information reports
summary: Amazon's plan to invest up to $50 billion in OpenAI could depend on whether ‌the AI developer goes public or achieves an artificial ‌general intelligence (AGI) milestone, The Information reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar ​with the matter.  Under terms still being negotiated, Amazon would invest $15 billion upfront, with an additional $35 billion contingent on Microsoft-backed OpenAI hitting an AGI milestone or pursuing an IPO, according ‌to the report.  Additionally, ⁠SoftBank and Nvidia each plan to invest $30 billion in three installments over the year as ⁠part of the funding round, the Information added.

raw.headline: Amazon's $50 billion OpenAI investment may depend on IPO or AGI, The Information reports

Additionally, ⁠SoftBank and Nvidia each plan to invest $30 billion in three installments over the year as ⁠part of the funding round, the Information added.

headline: Amazon Tops Walmart As Revenue Leader While AI Shift Reshapes Valuation Story
summary: Amazon.com (NasdaqGS:AMZN) has surpassed Walmart to become the largest U.S. company by annual revenue, taking the top spot on the Fortune 500. At the same time, AI research leader David Luan is departing, with Peter Desantis stepping in to oversee Amazon’s AI research efforts. These developments coincide with Amazon’s move to integrate its AGI division more closely with AWS. For investors watching Amazon.com at a share price of $210.63, this revenue milestone highlights how far the company...
